derivation.yuyuan_name: late Middle English (as a medical term meaning 'repressing of infection'): from Old French, or from Latin repercussio(n-), from repercutere 'cause to rebound, push back', from re- 'back, again' + percutere 'to strike'. The early sense 'driving back, rebounding' (mid 16th cent.) gave rise later to 'blow given in return', hence sense 1 (early 20th cent.)

entry.def: If an action or event has repercussions, it causes unpleasant things to happen some time after the original action or event.

example.ex: It was an effort which was to have painful repercussions...
example.tran: 这么做会带来极坏的负面影响。

example.ex: Members of congress were warned of possible repercussions if their vote went through.
example.tran: 国会议员被警告如果他们的投票通过可能会带来不良影响。

means.word_mean: 1. a remote or indirect consequence of some action;

sentences.sentence: "reverberations of the market crash were felt years later"

means.word_mean: 2. a movement back from an impact

auth_sentence.content: Our election from God is the repercussion of the beams of his love shining upon us.

auth_sentence.res_content_con: Our election from God is the repercussion of the beams of his love shining upon us.

auth_sentence.content: But these should not have a negative repercussion on Franco-German relations, said Susanne Wasum-Rainer.

auth_sentence.res_content_con: But these should not have a negative repercussion on Franco-German relations, said Susanne Wasum-Rainer.

stems_affixes.word_buile: con全部+cuss摇动,敲打,震+ion动作或状态→全部摇动
per自始至终+cuss摇动,敲打,震+ion动作或状态→一直震动
re一再+percussion[n.敲打;碰击;冲突;震动]→一再引起震动
dis分开+cuss敲打→把[问题]分开敲→讨论

sentences.cn: 改革带来了意想不到的后果。

jushi.english: Human acts have repercussions far beyond the frontiers of the human world.
jushi.chinese: 人类行为所产生的影响远远超出人类世界的范围。
